items.title: Why Pete Hegseth Summoned Top Military Leaders
items.summary: Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth faced a room of hundreds of generals and admirals whom he had summoned from across the globe, and made his case for shaking up a force that he said had gone soft and “woke.” Greg Jaffe, the Pentagon reporter for The New York Times, discusses Hegseth’s speech.

items.title: Environmental Protection Agency Employees Working Despite Furloughs Plan
items.summary: E.P.A. employees said that they were working without pay, and that Trump administration officials had not told them how long the funding would last. Union officials said they were “highly confused.”

items.title: How Washington Became a Testing Ground for ICE
items.summary: A series of arrests captured on video reveal how immigration officers have worked with other law enforcement agencies to identify migrants during stops for minor infractions.

items.title: Congress Remains Deadlocked as Shutdown Enters First Day
items.summary: Dueling proposals to extend government funding both failed for the third time in two weeks, as neither party could muster the bipartisan coalition needed to move forward.

items.title: How Government Shutdowns Got More Severe and Further Reaching
items.summary: Shutdowns started having significant effects after an attorney general in the 1980s argued that it was illegal for the government to spend money without congressional appropriations.

items.title: Supreme Court Allows Lisa Cook to Remain at Fed, for Now
items.summary: The justices deferred a decision on the president’s efforts to oust Ms. Cook and instead set oral arguments in the case for January.

items.title: US government shutdown live: White House says ‘layoffs are imminent’ as JD Vance uses false claims to blame Democrats for shutdown
items.summary: <p>Vice-president falsely claims that Democrats want to fund healthcare for ‘illegal aliens’ as press secretary says shutdown will affect federal workers</p><ul><li><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/01/us-government-shuts-down">US government shuts down</a></p></li><li><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ng-interactive/2025/sep/30/us-senate-government-funding-votes">Tracker: how each US senator voted</a></p></li></ul><p>This shutdown is expected to be worse than previous ones. The impact on federal workers could be even more severe.</p><p>Before Trump’s most recent threat of mass layoffs on Tuesday, a memo released last week by the White House’s office of management and budget told agencies not just to prepare for temporary furloughs <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/sep/25/trump-administration-government-shutdown">but for permanent layoffs</a> in the event of a shutdown.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/live/2025/oct/01/us-government-shutdown-update-2025-shutting-funding-trump-democrats-republicans-live-updates-latest-news">Continue reading...</a>

items.title: Democrats liken Trump to Putin after call to use US cities for military training
items.summary: <p>Illinois governor JB Pritzker and others condemn the US president for suggesting cities be used as military training grounds</p><p>A leading <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/democrats">Democrat</a> has compared Donald Trump to Russian dictator Vladimir Putin after the US president <a href="https://zpstrategies.us21.list-manage.com/track/click?u=abfa3589981adf5348ff20f1c&amp;id=b25801bfe3&amp;e=223fc5f871">told</a> military leaders on Tuesday that the armed forces should use US cities as “training grounds”.</p><p>JB Pritzker, the governor of Illinois, which is bracing for Trump to deploy national guard troops to his state, questioned the president’s mental health and accused him of behaving like an autocrat.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2025/oct/01/democrats-jb-pritzker-trump-putin-immigration">Continue reading...</a>
